comments.author: Kemonte Moore

top_comment.text:
Way to trivialize suicidal thoughts and loved one's reactions to them. I'm 
not saying this just to be negative, just pointing out that it's kind of 
insensitive. Perhaps you need to reevaluate your script instead of your 
diet.﻿
top_comment.author: seashmore

comments.text:
+Shannen A As someone who has dealt with depression and had friends commit 
suicide I find it hard to believe that someone who has overcome suicidal 
thoughts would still be sensitive on the subject, I don't want to seem over 
dramatic but have you looked in the mirror and asked yourself why it 
effects you? Have you considered that you may not be completely past 
whatever it was that made you contemplate suicide in the first place? Most 
comedy is taking serious problems and shining a new light on them that 
helps us laugh instead of crying, if you are not there yet you may want to 
serious ask yourself why.
I would also like to add that people eating food that is slowly killing 
them is no less tragic than the people who kill themselves faster. That is 
part of the humor of this skit, its the irony of him thinking they see him 
jumping when in fact they see poor eating habits that also lead to an 
undesirable outcome.
comments.author: berbandis

comments.text:
+Shannen A I have suicidal thoughts every day and I think this sketch is 
hilarious and it really shines a light on the absurdity of the whole 
suicide BS. It's a respectful sketch, it doesn't make fun of depression and 
it doesn't insult or ridicule anyone. It only plays with our preconceptions 
of a certain situation.
comments.author: nachoijp

comments.text:
+Shannen A But at the same time it's very clear that he has no intentions 
of committing suicide.
comments.author: Zeruckiven

comments.text: hjg
comments.author: Brandon Hobi

comments.text:
Studio C has always... well, trivialized things for the purposes of humor, 
which for me has always been hit or miss. If it's something like Algebra or 
Harry Potter, I don't mind their sarcasm, yet with something such as this I 
can easily see how it would offend some people. Especially those familiar 
with the topic in question.

Because it's purely for entertainment, and they have to pump out sketches 
constantly, they can't afford to take many things seriously. It's 
inevitable that some of their ideas will come across as insensitive as a 
result.
comments.author: Tohab

comments.text:
Wow... there's always one person who finds some bad in a perfectly good 
sketch.
comments.author: Brandon Hobi

comments.text:
I agree with you. However, as someone who's been suicidal in the past, it's 
hard to see people make jokes about it. It's like why you wouldn't make fun 
of someone with cancer. It's a tragic situation and one that shouldn't be 
taken lightly. You might find the analogy extreme, but they're pretty 
similar in seriousness.
comments.author: Shannen A

comments.text:
Nothing's funny these days if it has to be sensitive to qualify. I enjoyed 
the sketch and I don't think it's insensitive.
comments.author: Bethany Marie

comments.text:
This is really important, actually. I scoured through the comments on this 
video to see if anyone agreed with me and only found this one. I adore 
Studio C- it's one of my favorite shows- but this sketch isn't funny. At 
all.
comments.author: Shannen A
